poem:
Route 21 rumbles through bruised pavement  
its iron bones humming a verdict at midnight.  
Neon flickers against chain-link fences,  
spraying shards of color on rain-slick streets.  

The conductor’s voice crackles over speakers,  
spinning stories of deserted subways  
where phantom trains clatter through dark tunnels,  
each tale more gargantuan than the last.  

Steel wheels scrape the curve by the old foundry,  
sending sparks toward cracked sidewalks  
where possums freeze beneath the glare  
of passing headlights—no mercy granted.  

Smokestacks cough ash into the heavy air,  
clinging to your skin like a stain you’ll never wash off.  
Route 21 demands punctuality,  
collecting fare in the currency of grit and iron.  

Behind every stoplight, buildings loom  
with shuttered windows and whispered rumors,  
while the city exhales exhaust  
and the pulse of this steel corridor  
beats out a promise:  
you will move, you will endure,  
and you will never know where the next tall tale ends.
